title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions related to pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with demonstrated effectiveness in providing peer-to-peer training on literacy promotion to healthcare providers. This training curriculum is delivered in various medical education settings. The "Prescribe A Book Act" aims to support literacy promotion in healthcare settings by providing training in various medical education settings, offering technical assistance to implement Pediatric Early Literacy Programs, and integrating research into training curriculums. The "Prescribe A Book Act" supports literacy promotion in healthcare by integrating developmental research into training curriculums for healthcare providers. It defines the Pediatric Early Literacy Program as a model involving trained healthcare providers promoting early language and literacy. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes early language and literacy by having nurses encourage parents to read aloud to children and healthcare providers give children new books at health visits. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes early language and literacy by providing developmentally appropriate children's books to take home, having volunteers read aloud in healthcare facilities, and demonstrating effectiveness in altering parent behavior regarding reading aloud to children. The "Prescribe A Book Act" aims to improve expressive and receptive language in young children and gain the endorsement of medical associations. The "Prescribe A Book Act" authorizes the Secretary to award grants to eligible entities for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit an application with required information. Matching requirement is also specified. The "Prescribe A Book Act" requires eligible entities receiving grants to provide non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 50% of the grant received. Matching funds can be in cash or in-kind. Grant funds must be used as specified. An eligible entity receiving a grant under section 5622 must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies to establish and operate a Pediatric Early Literacy Program. Training and technical assistance must be provided to each contractor, and additional terms may be included as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may include additional terms in agreements with contractors to ensure program effectiveness. Contractors are selected based on serving at-risk children, including those from low-income families and without adequate medical insurance. Children who may be involved in the program include those in high-poverty areas, without adequate medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP, living in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited library access. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities have arrangements with book publishers or distributors to obtain books at favorable discounts before making any payments under this subpart. Additionally, there is a reporting requirement outlined in Section 5627. "An eligible entity receiving a grant under section 5622 must report annually to the Secretary on program effectiveness and describe each program. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act is amended to include a new subpart for pediatric early literacy programs." Subpart 22 focuses on pediatric early literacy programs, including definitions, program authorization, applications, matching requirements, use of grant funds, restrictions on payments, and reporting requirements.
